document.docAuthor: Zhu, Jia-Chen, Achterberg, Cornelis Van & Chen, Xue-Xin
document.docTitle: Alysia stenopos Zhu & Achterberg & Chen 2018, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the genus Alysia Latreille (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Alysiinae), with description of six new species from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the genus Alysia Latreille (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Alysiinae), with description of six new species from China

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURE 11. Alysia stenopos sp. n., ♀, holotype, habitus, lateral aspect.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURE 12. Alysia stenopos sp. n., ♀, holotype. A, fore wing; B, hind wing; C, mesosoma, dorsal aspect; D, mesosoma, lateral aspect; E, propodeum, first and second metasomal tergites, dorsal aspect; F, propodeum and metasoma, dorsal aspect; G, ovipositor and ovipositor sheath, lateral aspect; H, head, dorsal aspect; I, head, anterior aspect; J, head, lateral aspect; K, mandible, full view on first and second teeth; L, mandible, full view on third tooth; M, basal segments of antenna, lateral aspect; N, hind leg, lateral aspect.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material .
Holotype , ♀ ( ZJUH ), “
[NE. China :] Jilin
, Mt. Changbai , 6.?.1999, lin Naiquan No. 20035568”
.
Paratype : 1♀ ( ZJUH ), same data as holotype, but No. 20035567
.

Description .
Holotype , ♀ , length of body 3.6 mm , of fore wing 4.0 mm.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11.
Alysia stenopos
sp. n.
, ♀, holotype, habitus, lateral aspect.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Females have body length 3.6–4.0 mm, and length of fore wing 4.0– 4.4 mm .

Comparative diagnosis. This species is similar to
A. avatsha Belokobylskij
but differs by having the hind tarsal claws lacking a small lobe ( versus claws with a small lobe in
A. avatsha
); comparatively wide face, 2.5 × wider than high ( versus 1.8–2.0), and mandible with small incision between first and second tooth ( versus without incision).

Etymology .
Named “
stenopos
” because of the low face: “ steno ” is Greek for “narrow” and “ opos ” is Greek for “face”.
